Expectation1: Respect the mentor's time and availability.
Situation1: The mentor has set aside open office hours throughout the week.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: The build is stalled because no one can proceed until their core module is complete
Story: I stared at the blinking cursor on my screen, the code for the core module half-finished and the clock ticking past 3 p.m. My team’s messages kept popping up, each one more urgent than the last: “Any update on the module?” “We’re blocked until you finish.” I knew the project’s timeline hinged on me, and the pressure to deliver was suffocating. But then I remembered my mentor’s office hours—she’d set aside this time specifically for us to ask questions and get guidance. I’d promised myself I’d make the most of her availability, to show respect for her commitment and not waste the opportunity. Yet, if I left my desk now, the build would remain stalled, and my team would be left waiting. If I stayed, I’d be letting down my mentor, who always emphasized the importance of showing up and being proactive. My mind raced, torn between the responsibility to my team as an engineer and my commitment as a mentee. I hovered over the “Join Meeting” button, heart pounding, caught in the impossible tug-of-war between two roles I cared about deeply.
